commentary_on_process:
To solve the problem, I subtracted the percentage of pre-tax income earned by the top 1% of income households in 1979 from the percentage earned in 2007. This gave me the difference between the two percentages, which was 10%. 

To solve the problem more efficiently, I could have used a calculator to subtract 9 from 19, which would have given me the answer of 10 without having to do the mental math. Additionally, I could have double-checked my work by calculating the percentage difference between the two percentages, which would have been (19-9)/9 x 100 = 111.1%. This would have confirmed that the top 1% of income households earned 10% more of the pre-tax income in 2007 than they did in 1979.
problem_text:
Context:
Income inequality has become a hotly debated topic globally. According to the CIA World Factbook, U.S. income inequality ranked 41st highest among 156 countries in 2017 (i.e., 74% of countries have a more equal income distribution). According to the Congressional Budget Office, the top 1% of income households earned about a 9% share of the pre-tax income in 1979, versus 19% in 2007 and 17% in 2014. For after-tax income, these figures were 7%, 17%, and 13%, respectively. These figures indicate the share of income earned by top earners more than doubled between 1979 and 2007, then fell somewhat following the Great Recession, and the higher tax rates and re-distributive policies applied by President Barack Obama in 2013 (i.e., expiration of the Bush Tax Cuts for the top 1% and subsidies for lower income persons via the Affordable Care Act). Recasting the 2012 income using the 1979 income distribution (representing the more egalitarian 1950-1980 period), the bottom 99% of families would have averaged about $7,100 more income. Income inequality in the United States has grown from 2005 to 2012 in more than 2 out of 3 metropolitan areas.

Question:
How many more percentages did the top 1% of income households earn pre tax of 19% in 2007 than 9% in 1979?
question_alone: How many more percentages did the top 1% of income households earn pre tax of 19% in 2007 than 9% in 1979?

steps.step_response: We have read a passage about income inequality in the United States and a specific statistic related to the share of pre-tax income earned by the top 1% of income households in 1979 and 2007. We have been asked to calculate the difference between these two percentages.

type_of_step.name: Summarize what we've done so far
type_of_step.text: Please summarize what we've done so far. Please be concise and professional. Do only this step and do not jump ahead.

steps.usefulness_commentary: This helped me understand the context of the problem.

steps.step_response:
To calculate the difference between the two percentages, we subtract the percentage in 1979 from the percentage in 2007: 

19% - 9% = 10% 

Therefore, the top 1% of income households earned 10% more of the pre-tax income in 2007 than they did in 1979.

type_of_step.text: Step through the math to solve this problem. Please be concise and professional. Do only this step and do not jump ahead.

steps.step_response:
To solve the problem, I subtracted the percentage of pre-tax income earned by the top 1% of income households in 1979 from the percentage earned in 2007. This gave me the difference between the two percentages, which was 10%. 

To solve the problem more efficiently, I could have used a calculator to subtract 9 from 19, which would have given me the answer of 10 without having to do the mental math. Additionally, I could have double-checked my work by calculating the percentage difference between the two percentages, which would have been (19-9)/9 x 100 = 111.1%. This would have confirmed that the top 1% of income households earned 10% more of the pre-tax income in 2007 than they did in 1979.
